dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: 48% of Americans now see just a minor economic adjustment ahead, down from 52% earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: forty eight percent of Americans now see just a minor economic adjustment ahead, down from fifty two percent earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 50% of respondents see a major recession right around the corner, an increase from 46% earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's despite, um, what the study calls robust economic growth and relaxed trade agreements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's despite, um, what the study calls robust economic growth and relaxed trade agreements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a backdrop of slowing economic growth, ongoing geopolitical concerns and almost 15 months of trade tensions, more Americans are worrying about a looming downturn this year, according to the latest Allianz Quarterly Market Perceptions Study.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's interesting—Gen Xers are actually the most concerned generation at 58%, even more than Millennials or Boomers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's interesting-Gen Xers are actually the most concerned generation at fifty eight percent, even more than Millennials or Boomers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials remain the most concerned out of any generation: 56% said they are worried about a major market downturn on the horizon, compared to 51% of Gen Xers and 46% of Baby Boomers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of surprising, because you'd think with market stability lately, people would feel better. But Kelly LaVigne from Wells Fargo pointed out that Gen X might be extra cautious since they have less time to recover from big losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of surprising, because you'd think with market stability lately, people would feel better. But Kelly LaVigne from Wells Fargo pointed out that Gen X might be extra cautious since they have less time to recover from big losses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Market volatility didnt take a vacation this summer, LaVigne said in a statement. While Millennials might be most worried about a recession, they seem to be feeling more at peace about their situationlikely because they have more time to recover from any major losses, describes Kelly LaVigne, vice president of Advanced Markets, Allianz Life.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And on the flip side, Baby Boomers are way more comfortable investing now—50% of them said it's a good time, compared to only 17% of Millennials.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And on the flip side, Baby Boomers are way more comfortable investing now-fifty percent of them said it's a good time, compared to only seventeen percent of Millennials.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the flip side, Millennials are the most comfortable with recent market volatility: 47% would invest now, compared with just 17% of boomers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's a huge gap. And speaking of confidence, 72% of people now say it's important to have retirement savings in market-based products, up from 68% last quarter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's a huge gap. And speaking of confidence, seventy two percent of people now say it's important to have retirement savings in market-based products, up from sixty eight percent last quarter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recession fears have also resulted in fewer people saying its important to have retirement savings in financial products shielded from market losses: only 66%, compared to 72% last quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So even with some lingering worries, there's definitely a shift toward optimism. LaVigne mentioned that market stability "took a vacation this summer," which probably helped ease fears.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even with some lingering worries, there's definitely a shift toward optimism. LaVigne mentioned that market stability took a vacation this summer, which probably helped ease fears.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Market volatility didnt take a vacation this summer, LaVigne said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with trade talks with Japan looking promising, plus that yield curve normalizing since May, it makes sense that anxiety is fading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with trade talks with Japan looking promising, plus that yield curve normalizing since May, it makes sense that anxiety is fading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ongoing uncertainty over trade negotiations with Chinascheduled to resume on Thursdaycontinue to take center stage and stoke recession fears, as prospects for a comprehensive trade deal look gloomy. Whats more, the yield for the three-month Treasury has been higher than the ten-year Treasury since May: Known as an inverted yield curve, its a major indicator that has predicted the past seven recessions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like people are finally believing the good news—or at least, uh, trusting it enough to consider investing again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like people are finally believing the good news-or at least, uh, trusting it enough to consider investing again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fewer people are saying now is a good time to invest in the market: only 35% of respondents, compared with over 40% at the beginning of the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, you gotta wonder if this confidence will hold if any of those positive indicators start to wobble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, you gotta wonder if this confidence will hold if any of those positive indicators start to wobble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Economic sentiment can turn on a dime, but for now, it seems like a lot of Americans are breathing a sigh of relief.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Economic sentiment can turn on a dime, but for now, it seems like a lot of Americans are breathing a sigh of relief.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With major fluctuations over the past quarter, its not surprising that Americans are skittish about investing and worried that a market crash and recession might be around the corner.

artist_script:
HostA: 48% of Americans now see just a minor economic adjustment ahead, down from 52% earlier this year.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s despite, um, what the study calls robust economic growth and relaxed trade agreements.
HostA: Right, and it’s interesting—Gen Xers are actually the most concerned generation at 58%, even more than Millennials or Boomers.
HostB: Which is kind of surprising, because you’d think with market stability lately, people would feel better. But Kelly LaVigne from Wells Fargo pointed out that Gen X might be extra cautious since they have less time to recover from big losses.
HostA: Exactly. And on the flip side, Baby Boomers are way more comfortable investing now—50% of them said it’s a good time, compared to only 17% of Millennials.
HostB: Wow, that’s a huge gap. And speaking of confidence, 72% of people now say it’s important to have retirement savings in market-based products, up from 68% last quarter.
HostA: So even with some lingering worries, there’s definitely a shift toward optimism. LaVigne mentioned that market stability “took a vacation this summer,” which probably helped ease fears.
HostB: For sure. And with trade talks with Japan looking promising, plus that yield curve normalizing since May, it makes sense that anxiety is fading.
HostA: It’s like people are finally believing the good news—or at least, uh, trusting it enough to consider investing again.
HostB: Still, you gotta wonder if this confidence will hold if any of those positive indicators start to wobble.
HostA: Absolutely. Economic sentiment can turn on a dime, but for now, it seems like a lot of Americans are breathing a sigh of relief.
